title: How to setup a Quarto blog with gh-pages
text: This is the first post in a Quarto blog. And since I do not know how to setup my gh-pages with it, I just write about how I found out.

title: How to setup a Quarto blog with gh-pages
text:
Setup a Quarto Blog template
First things first. I am using RStudio‚Äôs ‚ÄúCreate Project‚Äù-dialog to use the ‚ÄúQuarto Blog‚Äù template. Let the screenshots speak for themselves:

title: How to setup a Quarto blog with gh-pages
text:
Deploying using GitHub Actions
Starting from here, I decide to take route number 3 (Use a GitHub Action to automatically render your files).
As recommended, I add the /_site/ directory to my .gitignore file.
Then, in order to keep code only executing locally, freeze the computation


_quarto.yml

execute:
  freeze: auto

Next, I create a file named publish.yml


.github/workflows/publish.yml

on:
  workflow_dispatch:
  push:
    branches: main

name: Quarto Publish

jobs:
  build-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: write
    steps:
      - name: Check out repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v3

      - name: Set up Quarto
        uses: quarto-dev/quarto-actions/setup@v2

      - name: Render and Publish
        uses: quarto-dev/quarto-actions/publish@v2
        with:
          target: gh-pages
        env:
          GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

Now, I check everything into my git repository and push to github. gh-pages should be initialized and I am ready to go.
As described here I use {usethis} to initialize my github credentials, so first I have to install the package:

install.packages("usethis")


credentials::set_github_pat() # and enter your PAT

If you don‚Äôt have a PAT, follow the instructions in the link above. To store the token permanently, use the .Renviron file of your project.
It is really easy! But I don‚Äôt know why, I had to create the branch gh-pages on the remote manually to make the build-job work. Before github actions were failing with a error hinting to a missing _publish.yml. Here I found out about the missing branch.

title: How to change the HTML theme of your Quarto Blog
text: Now that I have a running Quarto Blog setup on GitHub, I want to look into themes.

title: How to change the HTML theme of your Quarto Blog
section: Change themes for your Quarto Blog
text:
Change themes for your Quarto Blog
As described here, it should be pretty easy to set a different theme for the blog. I want to try the darkly theme of Bootswatch. So I just change the string in following file


_quarto.yml

format:
  html:
    theme: darkly

That‚Äôs it.

title: How to create a normal distribution plot using Python and Quarto
text:
Layout
I noted that the plot is bigger than the width of the blog. (This effect was gone later‚Ä¶) So I search for some possibilities to adjust and here is a good starting point.
Here I use the hash-pipe to set the layout, with one picture of width 100:
```{python}
#| layout: [[100]]
plt.plot(x_axis, norm.pdf(x_axis, 0, 1))
plt.show()
```







The outer squared brackets indicate the whole layout, where the inner squared brackets are the first row, that is here filled 100% with one plot.
It is also possible to set more than one figure:
```{python}
#| layout: [[50, 50]]
plt.plot(x_axis, norm.pdf(x_axis, 0, 1))
plt.show()

plt.plot(x_axis, norm.pdf(x_axis, 1, 2))
plt.show()
```










Here is some example code from the quartos docs, that I quite like. But in the quarto docs they use fixed image-files to simulate the output, where I use a duplicated codeblock, once with a header
``` {{python}}
and once as a normal codeblock with #| echo: false to suppress the output of the code, but to generate the figure.
This example code generates a tabset to compare python and R, I guess I will use this a lot in the future.

JupyterKnitr


```{python}
#| layout-ncol: 2
#| fig-cap: 
#|   - "Line Plot 1"
#|   - "Line Plot 2"
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.plot([1,23,2,4])
plt.show()
plt.plot([8,65,23,90])
plt.show()
```






Line Plot 1







Line Plot 2

#| fig-cap: 
#|   - "Speed and Stopping Distances of Cars"
#|   - "Vapor Pressure of Mercury as a Function of Temperature"
